item.title: China-Led Infrastructure Bank Finds No Evidence of Communist Party Influence
item.description: Beijing-backed AIIB conducted an internal review after its communications director resigned and leveled accusations.

item.title: Read the Ingredients Before Buying This $25 Billion ETF
item.description: Microsoft, Amazon and Netflix ended up as large holdings in a popular value-investing index created by S&P, an example of Wall Street tripping over itself.

item.title: Dollar Trades Steady, Weak US Jobs Data Could Send It Lower
item.description: The dollar was steady in Europe as traders awaited the U.S. jobs report and UniCredit Research said softer-than-expected data might spark some short-covering against the greenback.

item.title: Crude Oil Rises as Momentum Gains From Supply Cuts
item.description: Crude futures made solid gains in early European trading, with supply cuts from Saudi Arabia and Russia at the start of the week starting to have an impact on prices.

item.title: Strong Dollar, Weak Demand Tapers Metal Prices
item.description: A strong dollar was keeping metal prices in check, with weak demand and uncertain economic outlook adding further headwinds, said Fitch’s BMI.

item.title: 'The Out-Laws' Review: Brosnan, Barkin, Bandits and Banks
item.description: Produced by Adam Sandler, this Netflix comedy features Adam DeVine as a man who suspects his future in-laws are robbers, and it delivers more cringe than laughs.

item.title: Shell to Book Charge as Upstream Output Falls
item.description: UPDATED: Shell said it expected to book after-tax impairments of up to $3 billion for the second quarter of 2023, and that upstream production declined from the first three months of the year.

item.title: German Industrial Output Unexpectedly Dips
item.description: Industrial production in Germany fell 0.2% in May, a sign the country’s key manufacturing base could be struggling as global demand slows.

item.title: Dozens Injured After Two Buses Collide in New York
item.description: At least 18 people were sent to hospital with non-life-threatening injuries and dozens were treated at the scene, after a double-decker tour bus crashed into a commuter bus on the East Side of Manhattan on Thursday evening.

item.title: Eurozone Sovereign Bond Yield Spreads Seen Widening Slightly by Year-End
item.description: Macroeconomic fundamentals, issuance volumes and quantitative tightening flows shouldn’t be a concern for eurozone government bond yield spreads in the second half of the year but the market focus is likely to turn from duration to credit risk, as the end of the tightening cycle draws nearer, Societe Generale said.

item.title: Nikkei Falls 1.2%, Dragged by Electronics, Auto Stocks
item.description: Japanese stocks ended lower, dragged by falls in electronics and auto stocks, as concerns persist over the Fed’s further tightening.

item.title: Clariant Lowers 2023 Guidance on Disappointing Second Quarter
item.description: Clariant forecast underlying earnings of CHF650-CHF700 million this year, with an Ebitda margin of 14.3%-15.1%, and lower than previously estimated sales, as preliminary second-quarter results showed weaker demand due to macroeconomic challenges.

item.title: Elon Musk's SpaceX Now Has a 'De Facto' Monopoly on Rocket Launches
item.description: The company’s rockets are ferrying astronauts, launching satellites and dominating any competition.

item.title: A Letter From the Editor in Chief
item.description: Today marks 100 days since our friend and colleague was detained while reporting in Russia. We will not rest until he is released, Emma Tucker writes.

item.title: EVAN GERSHKOVICH | DETAINED FOR 100 DAYS
item.description: Evan was detained 100 days ago while on a reporting trip to Yekaterinburg. He has been held in Moscow’s infamous Lefortovo Prison on an espionage charge that the Journal and the U.S. government vehemently deny. He has committed no crime. He only did his job as a journalist.

item.title: Samsung Electronics, the world's largest maker of memory chips, forecast a 96% drop in operating profit for its second quarter.
item.description: Samsung Electronics, the world’s largest maker of memory chips, forecast a 96% drop in operating profit for its second quarter.

item.title: Tesla joined 15 Chinese automakers in a pledge to avoid abnormal pricing and promote "core socialist values," months after it started a price war that disrupted China's EV industry.
item.description: Tesla joined 15 Chinese automakers in a pledge to avoid abnormal pricing and promote “core socialist values,” months after it started a price war that disrupted China’s EV industry.

item.title: Electric-vehicle sales in the U.S. surged by 50% in the first half of the year, although the pace of growth slowed amid a buildup of unsold EV inventory at dealerships.
item.description: Electric-vehicle sales in the U.S. surged by 50% in the first half of the year, although the pace of growth slowed amid a buildup of unsold EV inventory at dealerships.

item.title: NBCUniversal is streamlining its entertainment operations under veteran movie studio chief Donna Langley, giving her oversight of its entire content strategy, including television and streaming.
item.description: NBCUniversal is streamlining its entertainment operations under veteran movie studio chief Donna Langley, giving her oversight of its entire content strategy, including television and streaming.

item.title: The surge in U.S. workers quitting their jobs has abated since peaking during the pandemic, another sign that the nation's labor market is cooling from ultrahot levels as the Federal Reserve raises interest rates.
item.description: The surge in U.S. workers quitting their jobs has abated since peaking during the pandemic, another sign that the nation’s labor market is cooling from ultrahot levels as the Federal Reserve raises interest rates.
